reviews.review_msg: I got a C+, he is the reason I am not able to transfer into CMPT. that semester I took only CMPT 225, the quizzes were different from the assignments. I viewed my examed after it was marked and found several mistakes, got a 7% increase.

Ramesh's teachings are mediocre at best; Class moves slow and is boring. Taking MACM 101 with another prof will almost guarantee a better learning outcome/experience. Ramesh is also almost never accessible out side of class. Midterms takes a month to mark and another two months to see your exam. Overall, TERRIBLE prof.
lecture slides are useless and ramesh can't teach at all. He just reads off the lecture slides with no emotion.

His lecture materials( class slides ) are arranged in a unreadable way and also, there are several concept mistakes in his given slides. Really frustrating when trying to apply these wrong theorems. Besides this, he only reads his slides out loud during lecture, not caring if people is keeping up.

the course isnt necessarily hard and ramesh isnt even necessarily a bad prof if you go to his office hours and ask for help... its just that his lectures in class are literally so bland and boring because he reads his notes out loud with little to no extra input... you can still do well in the class with self studying and trevtutor... lol
During the lectures he usually reads through his slides with few explanation, frustrating.

Seems like a nice guy but he can't teach. Just reads off the slides. Seems to have no idea how to use a computer. Assignments were basically free marks. Exams were okay. If you do better on the final than any / all of 3 the "quizzes", your final exam mark replaces those.

His lecture is useless and seldom reply email. It is CMPT225 but 50% of the content I felt like CMPT125. It is better to just reading the book and study at home. His quizzes are very boring (one question testing induction proof) and lack of marking standard. The average of quiz is about 60%. Just go for another professor...

I attended all his lectures and I'm still not sure what he's doing in any of those. It's like he's never used a computer before. He took the slides from someone else but didn't take the coloured version and then just read them. Assignments don't help you understand the course at all but very easy. Quizzes and Exams are extremely long.

Worthless lectures. Read the slides and textbook. The assignments are a free 100%, and basically pads up the class average. I suppose the quizzes and final were fair enough. The content itself could be interesting, but the instructor is just not good at introducing and explaining any of these concepts.
very hard prof.
if you want to learn something, don't take this prof.

Quizzes are simple. TAs were not hard markers. Answered a question completely wrong and still got 60% on it. Lectures and quiz questions sometimes do not make sense (Ramesh is not native English speaker). Lights are turned off during lectures. Final exam was difficult. Avoid if you want to learn, take if you want an easy A.
His quizzes and tests are too easy, not challenging.

lectures are slow. given HW which wont be marked from textbook, and saying the quiz will be different. does not give any sample quiz. youtube and the textbook have taught me more then this prof. additionally, he makes data structures boring.
He was a nice guy, but he just can't teach. Spends class time just reading over lectures and didn't care if I fell behind. He should at least gave more practice problems in class.

VERY boring lecturer but VERY fair exams. He is not a good presenter to say the least, but he is a genuinely nice guy if you actually seek for help outside of class. Just do all your homework and you'll be good.

I am a fourth year cmpt student. Still cannnot understand what he is talking about during the class. He explains the algorithm with very theoretical way, not even one specific number. If you are not good at this, avoid this professor. Very boring lecture, I think only 10 out of 50 people interested in what he is talking about.
Homework was due at the end of the term.
He's very modest and considerate,  and generally a nice guy. Straightforward lectures, he encourages you to ask questions and seek for help if needed. Deserves more respect.

Very good professor, explained material well, even though it was at times difficult. I learned a lot in the course under him. He simplifies some proofs in the textbook so attending lectures is essential. He is somewhat soft-spoken, so I suggest sitting near the front. Exams were somewhat difficult and consisted of 2-5 questions, but they were fair.
Terrible course with him.
Very boring algorithm class. He didn't bother even talking a little bit louder so that the second row students could have hear him. Very unfair exam and horrible final grades.

I don't know why dist ed kids found it hard. The lecture section was super easy. Labs were a joke, Projects were doable, MT was mostly theory (no cheatsheet), final exam had easy programs + substantial theory (even though 2pg cheatsheet allowed). Final grades are curved. Easy A+ for me though.

I am a fourth year, 3.8 GPA student. I took this class DE by the recommendation of my advisor. I failed the class, the final, and the midterm. The midterm is held after the drop deadline, there is no additional help from the Prof or TA's. If you're not already familiar with computer programing.. stay far away from this class.

I honestly can't say for sure that he was my prof, because he did not make one contact with me during my semester as a DE student. I have never received anything lower than a B+ in my three years at SFU. In this class I failed the midterm WITH A CHEAT SHEET. The TAs are given no structure by the prof, he does not communicate, and exams are too hard

Boring lectures (you can skip everyday and still understand cuz he posts notes) , very easy (like 10minutes per week) labs and assignments. (This coming from someone who've taken CMPT 120/125 before)  Midterm is fair, and covers a little of each topic. Overall, take the course because it's a GPA booster, not because the prof is a great guy and all.

apparently algorithm analysis and design equals proofs and graph theory, looking for a use for graph theory?, i mean really has anyone actually really used it in anything other than academics lately, lol
Very good teacher, has his own style. Easy to talk to and can always get help from - highly recommended
He is the best prof I had in SFU. He is clever, kind and modest. He is interested in the course material and welcomes you to talk to him at any time.
Very nice, kind and helpful. He is extremely smart and yet modest.
very good explanations.  Extremely intelligent prof.  Doesn't rush his lectures like other profs.

Awful. The worst prof i had at sfu. Not interested in teaching, no notes, writes on blackboard, horrible explanations, no clear solutions for exams and assignment. Run from him at all costs. Course is kinda hard on top of things.
Midterm was on the hard side, but he explains the material well.  He's really sharp and enjoys going beyond the required material.  Recommended for those who enjoy learning.
Comes in, flips open the book and starts copying on the board.  NO interest whatsoever in teaching.  Avoid at all costs.
Boring and can't understand him.  Exams are difficult.
Awful teaching style. The only good point is the easy marking in exams...

Very unenthused.  He could not explain any concepts, not even basic algorithms to the class.  I left his class more confused about algorithms than before I took the class.  Definitely an awful professor who should focus on publications more than teaching.
People aren't fair to him, he's not that bad... just very disorganized.

One of my worse professors ever at SFU.
 Lack of clarity. Difficulty: insane
avoid at all cost..can't teach at all..says everything's  stupid ..
he was my nightmare
No Comments
No Comments
cou;dt undestand this guy.made me quitcomp sci
the best ever!
very disorganized, worst prof i've ever had
No Comments
No Comments
No Comments
No Comments
worst prof i ever had
disorganized, doesn't devote enough time
